message_1: Solve the inequality 4x + 3 > 15 and graph the solution on the number line.
message_2:
To solve the inequality 4x + 3 > 15, we will first isolate the variable x by following these steps:

1. Subtract 3 from both sides of the inequality:
   4x + 3 - 3 > 15 - 3
   4x > 12

2. Divide both sides of the inequality by 4:
   4x/4 > 12/4
   x > 3

The solution to the inequality is x > 3.

To graph the solution on the number line, follow these steps:

1. Draw a number line with numbers from 0 to 6 (or more if you prefer).
2. Locate the number 3 on the number line.
3. Since the inequality is x > 3 (and not x â‰¥ 3), we will place an open circle at 3 to indicate that 3 is not included in the solution.
4. Shade the number line to the right of the open circle at 3, indicating that all numbers greater than 3 are part of the solution.

The graph of the solution on the number line will have an open circle at 3 and shaded to the right, representing all numbers greater than 3.
